NewsLines.HeadLine: UPDATE 5-Rebels step up attacks in Indian Kashmir on poll eve

NewsLine.NewsLineText: KASHMIR (UPDATE 5):UPDATE 5-Rebels step up attacks in Indian Kashmir on poll eve

body.p: (Adds comment from residents, Pakistan president, Indian deputy prime minister)
By Sanjeev Miglani and Sheikh Mushtaq

SRINAGAR, India, Sept 23 (Reuters) - Militants launched a string of attacks on security forces and political workers in Indian Kashmir on Monday as violence flared on the eve of a second round of a state assembly election, police said.
The attacks wounded 12 people and followed a gun battle between Indian forces and Muslim militants in which four rebels were killed, police said.

There was a brief exchange of gunfire between security forces and suspected militants near a polling booth in the state's summer capital, Srinagar, at nightfall on Monday but no injuries were reported.

Earlier, five soldiers guarding a Srinagar polling station were wounded when militants attacked with grenades, a police spokesman said. Another security man was hurt in a grenade blast in another part of the city.

Srinagar, along with the state's winter capital Jammu, will go to the polls on Tuesday to elect a parliament for Indian Kashmir, at the heart of a nine-month military standoff between nuclear-armed India and Pakistan.
Shops shut early as Srinagar, a city of 1.2 million people, prepared for the vote. Several residents said the election was no answer to the cycle of bloodshed.

"People are not involved in these elections, we need a healing touch, not elections," said Sheikh Mushtaq, a doctor. "There is too much disillusionment. Elections are just a dodging tactic. The basic issue of Kashmir has to be addressed," said Yaqub Jan, another resident.

Rebels have threatened to kill anyone involved in the election and separatist politicians have called for a boycott, saying the vote was no substitute for a U.N.-supervised plebiscite to decide if the Muslim-majority region should be part of India or Pakistan.

More than 35,000 people have been killed in the 13-year-revolt against Indian rule. More than 470 people, including a state minister and about 30 political workers, have been killed since the elections were called on August 2.
The first of four rounds of voting was held last week and the the last round will be on October 8.
TURNOUT DISPUTED
India is hoping the vote, which is being staggered to help security forces trying to ensure a peaceful vote, will boost the legitimacy of its rule and weaken the insurgency.
Indian Deputy Prime Minister L.K. Advani said he hoped the polls would help end separatist violence.
"I look forward eagerly to this election...changing the situation even further and making it possible for India to score...victory in this proxy war," Advani said in New Delhi.
India calls the violence by the rebels in Kashmir a "proxy war" waged by Muslim Pakistan and accuses Islamabad of training and arming the guerrillas -- charges Pakistan denies.
India sees the elections as a test of Pakistan's pledge to stop militants crossing into Indian Kashmir. Pakistan rejects the poll as a farce and says infiltration by militants has halted.
Indian authorities said turnout in the first round was a relatively strong 47 percent but separatist political leader Abdul Gani Bhat said the figure had been rigged.
Pakistani President Pervez Musharraf also dismissed the Indian turnout figure, saying only about 10 percent of voters, at most, went to the polls.

Thousands of soldiers have been deployed in Srinagar, Jammu and Budgam, the three districts that will vote on Tuesday, officials said. "Even though the threat of intimidation is unprecedented, our preparedness is also unprecedented," said chief electoral officer Pramod Jain.

The Greater Kashmir newspaper quoted the Hizbul-Mujahideen guerrilla group as saying it had ordered attacks on polling stations. The pro-Pakistan group warned government employees and voters to stay away from polling stations.
In Monday's violence, militants threw a grenade at a car carrying workers of a pro-India party in southern Kashmir. The grenade wounded six bystanders, police said.

Earlier, security forces gunned down four rebels near Banihal town. The area will vote on October 8. A soldier was killed and a soldier and a civilian wounded when militants triggered an explosion in southern Kashmir, police said.
An alliance of Kashmiri separatist political groups has urged a poll boycott, making victory for the state's ruling National Conference party, a pro-Delhi party, a virtual certainty.
